introduction.p: But, as you can check, the trinomial x^2+2x-5 cannot be factored.

So far we know two methods for solving quadratic equations: extracting roots and factoring. Neither of these methods applies to every quadratic equation. In this Lesson we consider a technique that works on all quadratic equations.

The graph of the quadratic equation y=ax^2+bx+c depends upon its coefficients, coefficientof quadratic equation a,~b, and c. In particular, the x-intercepts of the graph are determined by the values of these coefficients. In fact, there is a formula that uses the coefficients to calculate the solutions of the equation ax^2+bx+c=0. It is called the quadratic formula.

assemblage.title: The Quadratic Formula
assemblage.p: The solutions of the equation ax^2+bx+c=0,~~~~a \not= 0 are given by the formula \blert{x=\dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}}

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: The symbol \pm is used in this context to combine two similar formulas into one. It means that the quadratic equation has two solutions, namely \dfrac{-b + \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}~~~~\text{and}~~~~\dfrac{-b - \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}

statement.p: Use the quadratic formula to solve the equation x^2+2x-5=0

solution.p: The solutions of the equation are \dfrac{-2 + \sqrt{24}}{2} and \dfrac{-2 - \sqrt{24}}{2}. These are the exact values of the solutions. We can use a calculator to approximate each solution to hundredths. \dfrac{-2 + \sqrt{24}}{2} \amp \approx \dfrac{-2+4.90}{2} = 1.50 \dfrac{-2 - \sqrt{24}}{2} \amp \approx \dfrac{-2-4.90}{2} = -3.50 These values are very close to our estimates from the graph.

warning.p: Before we use the quadratic formula, we must write the equation in standard form so that we can identify the coefficients a,~b, and c.

subsubsection.title: Reading Questions

statement.p: How do we find the values of a,~b, and c in the quadratic formula?

answer.p: They are the coefficients of x^2 and x and the constant term, respectively.

subsubsection.p: If some of the coefficients are fractions, it helps to clear the fractions before applying the quadratic formula. The fastest way to clear all the fractions is to multiply each term of the equation by the lowest common denominator, or LCD, of all the fractions involved.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find decimal approximations to two decimal places for the solutions.

li.p: We use a calculator to approximate each solution. \dfrac{-6 + \sqrt{52}}{2} \amp \approx \dfrac{-6+7.21}{2} = 0.605 \dfrac{-6 - \sqrt{52}}{2} \amp \approx \dfrac{-6-7.21}{2} = -6.605 To two decimal places the solutions are 0.61 and -6.61.

subsubsection.title: Reading Questions

statement.p: If the coefficients in a quadratic equation are fractions, what should you do?

answer.p: Multiply each term of the equation by their LCD.

subsubsection.p: Of course, if a quadratic equation can be solved by factoring, then the quadratic formula will give the same solutions. You can use whichever technique seems faster for a particular equation.

sidebyside.p: The graph of y=x^2-4x+5 has no x-intercepts, as you can see in the figure at right. Nonetheless, we can use the quadratic formula to solve the equation x^2-4x+5=0

introduction.p: The solutions to the equation above are a type of number called complex numberscomplex number. If a quadratic equation does not have real-valued solutions, then its graph will not have x-intercepts.

assemblage.p: Every quadratic equation has two solutions. The nature of those solutions determines the nature of the x-intercepts of the graph.

assemblage.title: x-Intercepts of y=ax^2+bx+c
assemblage.p:
The x-intercepts of the graph of y=ax^2+bx+c are the solutions of ax^2+bx+c=0There are three possibilities.
If both solutions are real numbers, and unequal, the graph has two x-intercepts.
If the solutions are real and equal, the graph has one x-intercept, which is also its vertex.
If both solutions are non-real non-real complex numbers, the graph has no x-intercepts.

statement.p: If a quadratic equation has no real solutions, what does that tell you about the graph?

How many x-intercepts does the parabola have?

y=x^2-6x+9

li.p: We solve the equation x^2-6x+9 \amp = 0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Solve by factoring.}} (x-3)(x-3) \amp = 0 x-3=0~~~~x-3 \amp = 0 x=3~~~~x \amp = 3 This parabola has one x-intercept, (3,0).

statement.p: If the solutions of a quadratic equation are equal, what does that tell you about the graph?

answer.p: The graph has one x-intercept, which is also its vertex.
